description.plain:
The Jesus and Mary Chain are a Scottish Alternative Rock band formed by the two brothers, Jim and William Reid in 1983 with various bandmates joining them throughout the years.

Their debut, Psychocandy received critical acclaim and became a vastly influential album.

The band was influenced by The Stooges and The Velvet Underground and their sound successfully lands somewhere between the Stooges' noise and Lou Reed’s catchy lyrics.

The three following albums Darklands, Automatic, and Honey’s Dead also received highly positive reviews, but after rising tension between the members the band split up in 1999 shortly after their sixth (and least commercially successful) album Munki.

The band reformed in 2007 playing shows and releasing various box sets and greatest hit albums before recording a new studio album, Damage and Joy in 2017.

songs.full_title: Just Like Honey by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Just Like Honey

description.plain:
“Just Like Honey” is the third single released from The Jesus & Mary Chain’s debut album Psychocandy.

The song is a shining example of the band’s mixture of ‘60s pop and loud dissonant feedback. The drumbeat was famously borrowed from the classic Ronettes song, “Be My Baby.” This same beat was used on the track “Sowing Seeds” later on the album.

This song went on to be featured in 2004’s Lost In Translation, starring Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson.

songs.full_title: Never Understand by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Never Understand

description.plain:
“Never Understand” is the first single from Psychocandy. The song was originally released in February of 1985.

One of the more energetic ones on the record, “Never Understand” is  a driving, Noise-Punk anthem. The lyrics of the song display feelings of youthful angst as the subject of the song continually details his struggle with other people understanding him as a person.

songs.title: You Trip Me Up

description.plain:
“You Trip Me Up” is the second single from Psychocandy. The song was originally released in May of 1985.

The lyrics of the song talk about the subject’s strong feelings of love, and how it causes him to barely function, with him saying that he can barely even walk around this person.

songs.full_title: Reverence by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Reverence

description.plain:
Reverence is a song from the fourth album released by The Jesus and Mary Chain, 1992’s ‘Honey’s Dead’. The first single from that album, it was released in February 1992 and reached number 10 in the UK singles chart. It came with the b-side ‘Heat’.

The song itself exudes the cool and suave nature of the album as a whole, perhaps making it the perfect lead single. Lyrically, it keeps the cool, mysterious and romantic themes from past releases, with it perhaps referencing selling out or relationships or just goals in general.

body.plain:
Reverence is a song from the fourth album released by The Jesus and Mary Chain, 1992’s ‘Honey’s Dead’. The first single from that album, it was released in February 1992 and reached number 10 in the UK singles chart. It came with the b-side ‘Heat’.

The song itself exudes the cool and suave nature of the album as a whole, perhaps making it the perfect lead single. Lyrically, it keeps the cool, mysterious and romantic themes from past releases, with it perhaps referencing selling out or relationships or just goals in general.

songs.full_title: Snakedriver by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Snakedriver

description.plain: Not featured on any JAMC album and a rather overlooked song, Snakedriver was written and featured on the soundtrack for The Crow, released in 1994. More bluesy than the typical JAMC song, it’s lyrical content remains similar to their style, with an added layer of American sleaze and grit.

songs.title: Blues from a Gun

description.plain:
‘Blues From A Gun’ is a hit single from the third JAMC album, 1989s ‘Automatic’. The single reached number 32 on the UK singles chart and number one for three weeks on the US chart.

The song itself is simply about someone who gets the wrong signals from a target of their affections.

songs.full_title: Upside Down by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Upside Down

description.plain:
“Upside Down” is the first single released by the Jesus and Mary Chain.



The single was released on Alan McGee’s Creation Records in November 1984. McGee found the band through his friend Bobby Gillespie (the Chain’s future drummer), who gave him the band’s demo tape and asked him to book them a spot on the Creation Records night at the Roebuck pub in London. Though the band was seriously inebriated and played a set of incomprehensible, feedback-poisoned covers, McGee saw a hit and signed them on the spot.

The band, having had only a few months' practice at live performance and no recording experience save for their home demos, worked long hours into the night to record this single.

Lead singer Jim Reid on the recording session:

We’d work from midnight till about seven or something like that but we didn’t care; it was brilliant. The engineer that was there kept playing everything through these massive Tannoy speakers and everything sounded amazing. “Fucking hell!” we thought. “We didn’t realise we sounded so powerful!” We made this version of “Upside Down” and when we played it back it sounded like Dire Straits! We couldn’t work out why until someone pointed out we’d been playing it through these mega fucking blow-out–the-neighbourhood speakers and they’d make anything sound like The Velvet Underground so we had to go back in and remix it.
And we tried to do that and we did that classic thing where everybody’s in the studio saying, “Turn this up!” “No, turn that up!” so it was then decided that William [Reid] and Alan [McGee] would go in and mix “Upside Down”.

The single, originally pressed in an edition of 1,000, sold out quickly and went on to sell around 20,000 copies. It established Creation as a label to be reckoned with and garnered the Jesus and Mary Chain their first hints of fame.

Famed DJ John Peel was a fan of this record, putting it in his year-end Festive 50 in between The Smiths‘ “Reel Around the Fountain” and the Cocteau Twins’ “Pandora”.

songs.full_title: Vegetable Man by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Vegetable Man

description.plain:
“Vegetable Man” is the B-side to the Jesus and Mary Chain’s first single, “Upside Down”.



“Vegetable Man” was originally an unreleased Pink Floyd song, written by Syd Barrett. The band has, to this day, refused to officially release the song, often called one of Barrett’s most disturbingly unhinged moments as a songwriter.

The Jesus and Mary Chain frequently performed this song live in their early days (including at the gig which caused Alan McGee to sign them to Creation Records).

songs.full_title: Frequency by The Jesus and Mary Chain
songs.title: Frequency

description.plain:
The final track on the fourth JAMC album ‘Honey’s Dead’, the song ‘Frequency’ brings the album full circle with an almost reprise of the first track ‘Reverence’, closing the album with the very mission statement they started with, as if to reaffirm it and almost answer it.

It sounds almost happier and folkier than ‘Reverence’, maybe a hint as to the direction the band would take with ‘Stoned and Dethroned’.
